skill.name: commit-work
skill.description: Create high-quality git commits: review/stage intended changes, split into logical commits, and write clear commit messages (including Conventional Commits). Use when the user asks to commit, craft a commit message, stage changes, or split work into multiple commits.
skill.summary: Create production-ready git commits with proper staging, logical splitting, and Conventional Commits messages.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill contains only documentation files (README.md, SKILL.md) with git command examples and Conventional Commits format references. No executable code, no user input handling, no network calls, and no cryptographic operations exist in this skill.

content.value_statement: Creating quality git commits is time-consuming and error-prone. This skill automates commit creation with smart staging, logical splitting, and Conventional Commits formatting to produce review-ready commits every time.
actual_capabilities: Review working tree with git status and git diff to understand all changes
Split mixed changes into multiple logical commits using patch staging
Write Conventional Commits format messages with type, scope, and description
Verify staged changes before committing to catch secrets and debug code
Run relevant tests or checks before finalizing each commit
Provide clear commit summaries explaining what changed and why
limitations: Does not execute git commands directly - guides users through the workflow
Requires users to have git installed and access to their repository
Does not handle merge conflicts or rebase operations
Cannot access private commit history for context without explicit permission

use_cases.title: Prepare a feature branch for review
use_cases.description: Split a feature branch with mixed changes into clean, focused commits that are easy for teammates to review and understand.
use_cases.target_user: Developers working on feature branches who want clean commit history

use_cases.title: Write compliant commit messages
use_cases.description: Generate Conventional Commits format messages for projects that require standardized commit formatting for changelog generation.
use_cases.target_user: Contributors to projects using Conventional Commits specification

use_cases.title: Avoid mistakes in commit history
use_cases.description: Review staged changes before committing to catch accidentally included secrets, debug logging, or unrelated formatting changes.
use_cases.target_user: Developers who want to maintain clean, professional commit history

prompt_templates.title: Simple commit request
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me commit my work with a clear commit message.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to commit staged or unstaged changes

prompt_templates.title: Split complex changes
prompt_templates.prompt: I have mixed changes in my working tree. Help me split them into logical commits.
prompt_templates.scenario: User has multiple unrelated changes and needs help organizing them

prompt_templates.title: Conventional commits format
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Conventional Commits format message for my staged changes. Include what changed and why.
prompt_templates.scenario: User needs a properly formatted commit message

prompt_templates.title: Review before committing
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my staged changes for any secrets, debug code, or unrelated modifications before I commit.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to verify their changes are clean before committing

output_examples.input: User asks to commit a bugfix
output: Commit created: fix(auth): resolve token expiration edge case
Previously tokens would fail validation within 1 second of expiry due to clock skew. Now includes 5-second grace period.
Commands used: git status, git diff, git diff --cached
3. test: add coverage for profile endpoint
Each commit reviewed and verified separately.

best_practices: Always review git diff before staging to understand what will be included
Use patch staging (git add -p) when a file contains unrelated changes
Write commit messages that explain what changed and why, not implementation details
anti_patterns: Using git add . or git add -A without reviewing what will be committed
Creating large, monolithic commits that mix multiple concerns
Writing commit messages that only describe implementation details without context

faq.question: What is Conventional Commits format?
faq.answer: Conventional Commits is a specification that structures commit messages as type(scope): description. Common types include feat, fix, chore, docs, and refactor. This format enables automated changelog generation and semantic versioning.

faq.question: Does this skill run git commands?
faq.answer: No, this skill guides users through the git workflow by explaining what commands to run and when. The actual git commands are executed by the user or their Claude tool with appropriate permissions.

faq.question: How does patch staging work?
faq.answer: Patch staging (git add -p) allows you to review each change hunk in a file and decide whether to stage it, skip it, or split it further. This enables creating separate commits for different changes within the same file.

faq.question: Can I use this skill without Conventional Commits?
faq.answer: Conventional Commits are required by default, but you can ask for a different format. The skill will still follow the same workflow of staging, reviewing, and verifying changes.

faq.question: What checks are run before committing?
faq.answer: The skill prompts you to run the fastest meaningful check for your project, such as unit tests, linting, or a build command. The specific check depends on your project setup.

faq.question: How do I handle merge conflicts with this skill?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on commit creation, not conflict resolution. For merge conflicts, resolve them first using standard git merge tools, then use this skill to create clean commits.
